subject: Filtering image based on name contained

values.-1: This patch needs further work before it can be merged
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

messages.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

IMHO, this is not a bug but a RFE. So personally, I don't like to get it in v1 because we need git rid of v1 and embrace v2. And I think it deserves a test case. Cheers.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I think it's better do not touch v1 api at all. This changes is more reasonable to do on the db layer. For example there is a function in db/sqlalchemy/api.py called _make_conditions_from_filters which is exactly responsible for filter processing.

In that case both v1 and v2 api will be affected.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I agree. The v1 API shouldn't really be augmented at this point.
Uploaded patch set 3.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Why not add unit tests for the v2 API?

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Nice work here!

But I still have some remarks:

1. Once you have made the changes ??in sqlalchemy, then you have to write a test on it. (in glance/tests/unit/test_db.py)

2. I think you have to add the same changes in simple db too to maintain it in consistent state with sqlalchemy.

3. Since you've made changes in user interface you should add DocImpact to your commit message. If you look in the current documentation (http://docs.openstack.org/developer/glance/glanceapi.html#filtering-images-lists) you'll see "Filters images having a name attribute matching NAME". It has to be changed from matching to contain.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

This breaks backwards compatibility!

If some existing service consuming our API relies on the fact that filtering by name returns the exact match of the name (and thus returns 0 or 1 images if no name duplication exists), than they may face problems when we begin returning multiple images with similar names.

So, loosening the filtering precision does not look like a good idea to me. 
I would suggest to add some explicit differentiation between the "exact match" and "contains" calls, and make sure that by default the existing behaviour (i.e. the exact match) is used.

Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

Thx Alexander
I checked glance API docs and there is:
"Both the GET /v1/images and GET /v1/images/detail requests take query parameters that serve to filter the returned list of images."
So I think it should't hit client expected return value

Patch Set 3:

Right, but in the parameter description section it says: "Filters images having a name attribute matching NAME". 
And "matching" here seems to mean "equal" - at least all the existing functionality for all other parameters does it this way: checks for strict value equality.

Silently changing this from "equal" to "contains" may have unwanted side effects for the existing deployments.
Uploaded patch set 4.

Patch Set 6:

Hi Alexander.
I think you right in that one use case - user has a list with more than one name.
But IMHO, filtering image name based on one exactly matching name is useless for the user. I mean what's the point of filter, if user already knows exactly what a image name is.
I see that 'size_min(max)' is similar context (not with exactly matching size, but with less(greater) value).
cheers

Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1

I agree with Wlodzimierz: logically filtering by name signifies that we want all images with names contain input string.

I understand it breaks backward compatibility, but it's a rare case. I mean often images called something like cirros-0.3.2-x86_64-uec-ramdisk. If we need exactly one name, filtering by that string returns us what we want.

Imo we can discuss it on the weekly meeting.

Patch Set 6: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of the repository. Please rebase your change and upload a new patchset.
Uploaded patch set 7.

Patch Set 7:

I understand your concern and the idea is quite valid, however I would prefer to have a wider discussion (IRC?) on this topic, as it seems important to me.

Even more, it is not obvious why ?name=someName have "contains" semantics, while ?someOtherAttr=someValue mean exact equality. This makes API less obvious: it behaves differently for different attribute names, which should not be the case. 

Leaving -1 until further discussion.

Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

I agree with Alex.  This is silently changing the way the API works.  For a like match, there should be some API discussion on how to not affect the existing API.

Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

Did some discussion on this in IRC. I am still concerned about backwards compatibility, so -1 until I get more arguments for this.

Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

I agree with Wlodek that this call doesn't make sense if we stick to equals instead of contains. However, we need to keep API consistent, so -1 from me.

Abandoned

after all this time, I'd assume we don't need this patch anymore. The bug/blueprint was probably fixed already or invalidated. Please, feel free to re-open it if you think otherwise.
